docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Welcome to Reality documentation. This is a preview version of the SDK, for a full experience, please wait the final version.

Some information may change until the final version. To report issues, please use this link https://github.com/AtlasXRInc/Reality/issues If you need help, feel free to ask on the Beyond discord https://discord.com/invite/Zure49uSKR

docs.title: Download
docs.text: wip

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
• Download Unreal engine
  • Download the beginner's project

docs.title: Create a mod
docs.text: You can create many type of mods - GameMode mod Create custom rules for a game - Map mod Create your map and add support to gamemodes you want

docs.title: Create a new mod
docs.text:
• Click on Reality > New mod ...
  • Select the type of mod you want to create

Warning

Do not change the name of the generated file. The modsystem will search for this specific name to load mods.

docs.title: Map Mod
docs.text:
Note

Map mods will use Beyond world settings in-game. It's not required to set those settings.

docs.title: How to Get The Reality SDK (Beyond Sandbox Modkit)
docs.text:
• Download the Reality modkit installer (RealityInstaller.zip): https://github.com/AtlasXRInc/RealitySDK-dev/releases/tag/RealityInstaller
  • Unzip it in the folder where you want to install Unreality (our fork of Unreal).
  • It’s recommended to unzip it at the root directory (C:\RealityInstaller) to avoid issues with long file paths.
  • Open PowerShell as Administrator and navigate to the extracted directory:
cd path\to\RealityInstaller
  • Run the installer:
.\Install.bat

Warning

This requires at least 55 GB of free space.

  • The installer sets up:

    • Atlas XR’s Unreality Engine fork
    • The Reality Modkit plugin
    • ADB & Java (Used to build and sideload your mods to Quest)

Once installed, at the root of your installation folder, run Launch Unreal Editor.exe at least once to complete the setup.

docs.title: Understanding Unreality vs Reality
docs.text:
• Unreality is Atlas XR and Meta’s fork of Unreal Engine, optimized for VR. It’s updated rarely and is the base engine you’ll build on.
  • Reality is the modkit. It’s updated frequently and contains the SDK tools you’ll use when creating mods.

docs.title: If You Don’t Have a Modkit Unreal Project Yet
docs.text:
1. Open Unreality. It will take few minutes to compile the first time you open it.

  2. In the Unreal Project Browser:

    • Select Blank Project
    • Blueprint project (not C++)
    • Target platform: Mobile
    • Quality Preset: Scalable

  3. Click Create to make a new project.

Note

You may see a popup regarding Shader Model 6. This can be safely ignored.

  1. Once the project opens:

    • From the top ribbon, click Edit → Plugins.
    • Search for Reality.
    • Click the checkbox to enable it.
    • Restart the editor when prompted.

  2. Replace the config files with the provided Reality config files to match rendering and collision settings.

docs.title: If You Already Have a Modkit Project
docs.text:
1. Delete the old Reality SDK 0.1/.2 plugin.
  2. Make sure you are using the correct Unreal version. Right-click your .uproject file → Switch Unreal Engine version → select the path to Unreality.
  3. Replace the config files with the new Reality config files.

docs.title: Create Your First Mod
docs.text:
Once your project is set up:

  1. In the Unreal Editor, open the Reality dropdown (top menu bar).
  2. Select New Mod.

docs.title: Unreal Engine
docs.text: • Install Unreal Engine 5.5 https://www.unrealengine.com/fr/download

docs.title: Reality Plugin
docs.text:
• Download latest Reality plugin https://github.com/AtlasXRInc/Reality/releases
  • Install it to Plugins folder of your project

docs.title: Beyond Sandbox Meta Quest Dev Version
docs.text:
• Join the Beyond Sandbox dev channel (by the invite link)
  • Configure the channel on your Meta Quest
  • Open your content Library
  • Locate Beyond Sandbox and press on the "3 dots" icon to open the context menu
  • Press "Settings" and select "Beta (Dev)"

ModSystem

  • Rewrite from nmod
  • Mod manifests

RealityEditor

  • Multiplatform toolkit (android, windows)
  • ADB tools
  • Modio integration
  • Mod builder
  • Tasks system
  • UI

Reality

  • Game creation UI
  • Mod loading
  • Mods type
    • GameMode mod
    • Map mod
  • Final tests
  • Setup distribution pipeline to modders

RealityEditor

Reality

  • Object System
  • Modpack System
  • Advanced Game Mode Support
  • Interactable Support
  • Firearms Support
  • SDK API Tests
  • Software Occlusion Culling
  • PCVR Distribution
  • Unreality Distribution
  • Final tests

RealityEditor

  • QoL improvement

Reality

  • Multiplayer tests
  • Interoperability tests
  • Mods type
    • Skin mods
  • SDK API
    • GameAPI
    • CombatAPI

RealityEditor

  • Map mods can support external user-created GameMode mods
  • Add in-editor mod search
  • Project templates
  • Documentation

docs.title: Test a mod
docs.text:
Note

The build / run process will be improved in next versions

To test a mod, be sure you are using the dev channel of the game (see prerequisites)

docs.title: Cook
docs.text:
Select Platform > Android > Cook content to cook you mod content

For map mods, ensure that List of maps to include in a packaged build in Platforms > packaging settings contains your map, if not add it before cooking.

docs.title: Build
docs.text: Build the plugin using Reality > Build button

docs.title: Transfer
docs.text: From the Reality menu, select your device and click Transfer mod. You can check Unreal logs to see if it succeeded.

docs.title: Launch game
docs.text: Launch Beyond and use the game creation UI to select your gamemode and your map then start the game.

docs.title: Create Firearms
docs.text: A Reality Firearm is a specialized child class of Reality Interactable designed specifically for creating firearms in your mods. This class includes all the necessary functionality for handling VR weapon interactions, such as grabbing, aiming, firing, and physical collision.

docs.title: Creating a Reality Firearm Actor
docs.text:
1. Right-click in the Content Browser.
  2. Select Create Blueprint Class.
  3. Search for Reality Firearm.
  4. Choose it as the parent class for your new blueprint.

Once created, you can customize the firearm’s appearance, behavior, and mechanics by modifying the blueprint.

docs.title: Viewing Example Firearms
docs.text:
To explore example Reality Firearm blueprints:

  1. Open the Content Browser.
  2. Click Settings (top right).
  3. Enable Show Engine Content.
  4. In the Engine directory, search for RealityFirearm.

You’ll find example blueprints such as:

  • RealityFirearm_AK47_Example
  • RealityFirearmDoubleBarrelSawedOff_Example

These are great references to understand weapon setup, components, and functionality.

docs.title: Placement in Mod Folder
docs.text:
When you create a mod, a folder named ModName Content is automatically generated in the Plugins folder.

Make sure your Reality Firearm (and all dependencies i.e meshes, textures, animations) are saved inside this folder, or it will not be packaged with your mod.

docs.title: Scaling Interactables
docs.text:
Warning

Do not scale the Root Component directly. Changing the root component’s scale causes physics issues. (The Root Component is the top component in the Components hierarchy when a Blueprint is open)

Instead, use the UE5 Editor tools to adjust the size of your mesh:

  • Remodel or reimport the mesh at the correct scale.
  • Alternatively, use the Static Mesh Editor to adjust its import scale.

docs.title: Creating a Reality Interactable Actor
docs.text:
1. Right-click in the Content Browser.
  2. Select Create Blueprint Class.
  3. Search for Reality Interactable.
  4. Choose it as the parent class for your new blueprint.

Tip

Use Reality Interactable for anything that requires physics-based interaction.

docs.title: Examples of What Should Not Be Interactable
docs.text:
• Decorative props that don’t need physics interaction
  • Non-physical gameplay elements (e.g., trigger volumes, UI components)

docs.title: Converting an Existing Actor to a Reality Interactable
docs.text:
If you already have an actor and want to make it interactable:

  1. Open the existing actor’s Blueprint.
  2. In the top ribbon, click Class Settings.
  3. In the Details Panel, set the Parent Class to Reality Interactable.

docs.title: Viewing Example Interactables
docs.text:
To explore example Reality Interactable blueprints:

  1. Open the Content Browser.
  2. Click Settings (top right).
  3. Enable Show Engine Content.
  4. In the Engine directory, search for RealityInteractable.

You’ll find blueprints such as:

  • RealityInteractable_DoorHandle
  • RealityInteractable_Machete

These can be great references for setup and best practices.

docs.title: Placement in Mod Folder
docs.text:
When you create a mod, a folder named ModName Content is automatically generated in the Plugins folder.

Make sure your Reality Interactable actor (and all dependencies i.e meshes, textures, animations) are saved inside this folder, or it will not be packaged with your mod.

docs.title: Scaling Interactables
docs.text:
Warning

Do not scale the Root Component directly. Changing the root component’s scale causes physics issues. (The Root Component is the top component in the Components hierarchy when a Blueprint is open)

Instead, use the UE5 Editor tools to adjust the size of your mesh:

  • Remodel or reimport the mesh at the correct scale.
  • Alternatively, use the Static Mesh Editor to adjust its import scale.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A Reality Interactable is any physical object that players can interact with through their VR hands — such as weapons, doors, and other interactive props. This system enables objects to behave physically and deal damage appropriately (e.g., smashing a chair on someone’s head will cause damage).

docs.title: Sharp Area Component
docs.text:
The Sharp Area Component is a box collider component that enables stabbing and slashing interactions in your project. It can be used to create functional spikes, traps, bayonets, or bladed weapons.

You can choose to enable stabbing, slashing, or both — depending on the behavior you want.

docs.title: Adding a Sharp Area Component to a Blueprint
docs.text:
1. In the Components tab of your Blueprint, click Add.
  2. Search for Reality Sharp Area and select it.
  3. Position the component and align its scale and rotation with the sharp area on the Blueprint you are working with.

Tip: Sometimes you may need more than one Sharp Area Component to accurately simulate your weapon. For example, a katana may use one Sharp Area for the tip (stabbing) and another for the blade (slashing).

You can align the stab axis and slash axis either by:

  • Changing the corresponding variable in the dropdown, or
  • Rotating the entire component in the editor.

Note

For complex weapons like a rake, adding a Sharp Area Component to every spike is not recommended, as this may negatively impact performance.

docs.title: Variable Reference
docs.text: The following tables list all available variables for the Sharp Area Component, separated into Stabbing and Slashing settings.

docs.title: Stabbing
docs.text: Variable Description Can Stab Enables stabbing behavior for this sharp area. Stab Axis Axis aligned with the normal direction of the tip. Position Strength TODO Velocity Strength TODO Minimum Penetration Minimum distance required to count as a valid stab. Maximum Penetration Maximum distance the blade can penetrate. Stab Force Threshold Offset applied to the base stab force threshold. Negative requires less force to stab; positive requires more. Can Be Pushed Deeper Toggle on to allow the blade to be pushed deeper into the wound. When Can Be Pushed Deeper is disabled, the stab depth is calculated on the first collision frame and remains fixed at that depth. When enabled, the blade can continue to be pushed deeper into the target up to the Maximum Penetration distance after the initial stab. Can Twist Enables twisting of the blade after penetration. Twist Limit How far twisting is allowed (in degrees or custom units). Can Swing Whether the blade can swing from this area. Swing Limit How far the blade can swing (in degrees or custom units).

docs.title: Slashing
docs.text: Variable Description Can Slash Enables slashing behavior for this sharp area. Slash Force Threshold Offset applied to the base slash force threshold. Negative requires less force to slash; positive requires more. Slash Axis Axis that runs along the blade for slashing direction.

docs.title: Positioning Notes
docs.text:
• It's okay for Sharp Area Components to overlap slightly. Overlaps will not cause any issues in detection or interaction.
  • Make sure each Sharp Area’s scale and axis orientation match the physical shape and intended interaction area of the weapon.

docs.title: Example: Machete Setup
docs.text:
To see a working example of a Sharp Area Component:

  1. Open your Content Browser.
  2. In the top right, click Settings → enable Show Engine Content.
  3. In the Engine directory, search for RealityFirearm.
  4. Open the Blueprint called RealityInteractable_Machete.

This Blueprint demonstrates how Sharp Area Components are positioned and configured for both stabbing and slashing on a single weapon.
